H0.text: Charting where birds fly is not an example of observation and measurement.

H1.text: Attracting birds with birdseed is not an example of observation and measurement.

H2.text: Counting the number of birds that fly by is not an example of observation and measurement.

H3.text: Illustrating the different birds that fly by is not an example of observation and measurement.

A4.text: Birders may take part in censuses of bird populations and migratory patterns which are sometimes specific to individual species.

A5.text: Birders may also count all birds in a given area, as in the Christmas Bird Count.

A6.text: Satellite transmitters provide the ability to track migrating birds in near‑real time.

A7.text: Observations are made in the field using carefully designed protocols and the data may be analysed to estimate bird diversity, relative abundance, or absolute population densities.

A8.text: The Cornell Lab of Ornithology Food Preferences Chart documents bird food preferences.

A9.text: Data collection is a research component in all study fields, including physical and social sciences, humanities, and business.

A10.text: Quality assurance (QA) – all actions carried out before data collection.
